Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Cuff Inflation-Deflation and Conventional Techniques for Nasotracheal Intubation

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the conventional group (Group C) or the cuff inflation group (Group I) using block randomisation with a 1:1 ratio.

Participants.evidence: Participants were 106 patients aged 18-65 years, ASA I-II, scheduled for elective surgeries requiring NTI. Exclusion criteria included difficult airway, nasal trauma, and refusal to participate.

Intervention.evidence: compared to the conventional method for NTI.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of the cuff inflation-deflation technique compared to the conventional method for NTI.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intubation time, measured from oropharynx entry to successful end-tidal CO2 confirmation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was concealed using opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not possible for the anesthesiologists.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 53 patients were randomised to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Intubation time was significantly shorter in Group I (27.86 ± 4.47 s) compared to Group C (41.11 ± 10.98 s; P < 0.0001).

Harms.evidence: Mild to moderate nasal bleeding occurred in 5/53 patients in Group I and 8/53 in Group C.
